clinical_study.brief_title: Intra-op POCUS for Identification of Endotracheal Tube Position in the Pediatric Population
clinical_study.official_title: Intraoperative Point-of Care Ultrasound for Identification of Endotracheal Tube Position in the Pediatric Population

brief_summary.textblock: Chest X-ray and/or fluoroscopy is not routinely used in the OR to confirm endotracheal tube (ETT) placement by anesthesiologists. Multiple studies have shown that ~19% of all intubations result in inappropriate ETT placement. An adult study has shown that ultrasound point-of-care is superior to auscultation in determining the location of ETT. This study aims to determine if point-of-care is useful in determining ETT position in children.

detailed_description.textblock: Patients scheduled to have a procedure in the cardiovascular laboratory where fluoroscopy is routinely used will also undergo a point-of-care ultrasound exam to determine endotracheal tube position. An anesthesiologist will perform the ultrasound exam.

primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: The primary outcome marker for this study was the correlation between the weighted POCUS measurement of TT location and the weighted fluoroscopy measurement of TT location

clinical_study.condition: Endotracheal Tube Wrongly Placed During Anesthetic Procedure

arm_group.description: Child undergoing procedure in CVL requiring ETT and CXR as standard of care - received point-of-care ultrasound exam as part of the study

intervention.description: ETT will be repositioned based on CXR by fluoroscopy

study_pop.textblock: Children who require general anesthesia and endotracheal intubation for procedures in the cardiovascular laboratory
